titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. V:45. Tuesday. The Letter which I received last evening from Belles and Harrold made it necessary for me to go this morning to London— Just before leaving home I received Letters from my father and mother, and with the latter Mr Norton’s funeral Sermon, upon the death of Dr Tufts— The Letters are dated 2. and 3. May, and appear to have been brought by Mr Brooks. He perhaps thought them only Letters of introduction, and did not think it necessary to forward them upon his arrival in England— I went to London in the Curricle, and read the Sermon upon the way. Went first to the Foreign Office. Met in the Anti-chamber, the Chevalier de Freire, with Count Palmella, and a Secretary of the Russian Embassy.— After waiting a full half hour I saw the Under-Secretary of State Hamilton. Spoke to him about the warrant for the exportation of machinery for the Mint of the United States. Hamilton has just returned after an absence of two or three Months, and knew nothing of the state of the business of the Office— Planta is gone with Lord Castlereagh to Ireland— I mentioned my first Note to Lord Castlereagh, about the mint machinery—the Act of Parliament, passed in consequence of that application; a printed copy of which I had with me, and shewed him— My second Note to Lord Castlereagh after the act, and the verbal answer of Lord Castlereagh and Planta that the answer had been given. But I had no written answer; the intended exporters had now written to me to ask for the warrant for exportation, and I came to enquire whether the order was now in possession of the Officers of the Customs at Liverpool, and if not that it might be immediately despatched; as the machinery would be there in a day or two; and the vessel in which it was to be exported, would be ready to sail by the sixth or seventh of this Month— Hamilton told me that according to their forms
of business, the warrant for the exportation must be issued from the Home department, and signed by Lord Sidmouth. I observed that the Act of Parliament authorized anyone of the Secretaries of State to issue the warrant— He said that although the authority was general, it was exercised only by the Secretary for the Home Department. In this however Hamilton was mistaken— He sent to several of the Clerks, to enquire what had been done upon my application; at last Bidwell the Son came, and he sent him to the Treasury to ascertain whether the order to the Customs had been issued there. My Note to Lord Castlereagh could not be found, nor any record in the Office, relating to it— While Bidwell was gone, I spoke to Hamilton about the Notes which I had lately sent to Lord Castlereagh, and to which I had not received answers— He said he had just been reading my note proposing the negotiation of a commercial Treaty. I told him I had received a Letter from Lord Castlereagh, postponing the answer to that; but the Notes to which I referred were one respecting the refusal of the Officers of the Customs to return the extra Tonnage duties levied upon American vessels, unless they came directly from, or were bound directly to Ports of the United States— And one to request that the destitute American Seamen, shipped by order of the Consul on board of American vessels for conveyance to America may not be counted as part of the number of passenger’s limited to one person for every five tons of the vessels burthen— He said this case was so clear that he wondered there should have been a necessity for any application about it. I told him there was another practice of the Officers of the Customs on the subject of which I had not yet addressed a written Note, because I thought it best to mention it in the first instance verbally— I thought they were not warranted in the practice by the Law. I had been inclined to advise the parties interested to contest it at Law, by a process I supposed in the Court of Exchequer— But before giving this advice, I had preferred stating the case to the Government; so that if they thought proper they might issue an order to the customs to alter their practice, and make it conform to the Law—which would save the trouble and expence of a suit. The practice was, of allowing only one passenger for every five tons, of a vessel of what they call the unoccupied tonnage—that is, of the part in which there is no Cargo— I shewed him the two Acts of Parliament, and pointed out to him how the Officers of the Customs had unwarrantably applied the restriction in one Section of the first Act, to another Section, where it was not included— It was sometime before he understood me. He thought at first I meant to contend that by the new Act American Vessels were placed on a more advantageous footing than British Vessels; and said that if the Custom-house should be now obliged to alter their practice, it would only make it necessary to pass a new Act of Parliament at the next Session. When I had fully explained to him the real question, and he had attentively read over the provisions of both the Acts, he took minutes of them; and requested me to send him a Memorandum, not in the form of an official note; but exhibiting my view of the proper Construction of the Acts, and said he would attend to it— I enquired also about the exequatur for H. Visgers Commission as American Consul at Bristol; and after much research was told it was ready, and would be delivered if I would send for it to-morrow. Bidwell at length returned, and said the order from the Treasury to the Custom-House, for the exportation of the Mint Machinery had been sent on the 16th. of August. but it was still doubtful to me, whether it had been received by the Collector at Liverpool; so at the recommendation of Mr Hamilton, I went myself with Bidwell to the Treasury-Office, where a Clerk shewed me the record of the order from the Treasury to the Commissioners of the Customs, issued the 16th. of August, upon a Letter from Mr Planta. So it seems no signature of Lord Sidmouth, nor even of Lord Castlereagh was necessary in this case. The proxy of Planta’s name was sufficient. Still I had no certainty that the order had been sent to the Collector at Liverpool— Bidwell said it must have gone of course; but the Treasury Clerk referred me to the Secretary of the Commissioners of the Customs, at the Custom-House in the City. It was now close upon four O’Clock, and too late to go down there this day— After calling at two shops for the Bills of the Articles to be sent to T. B. Johnson’s, at a shoemaker’s and at Williams the Stationer’s for his Bill, I went to my Office in Craven-Street— The Coachman complained of being ill, and requested me to let him wait, and return home without putting up the horses. I found at my Office Dr Cook, the Navy chaplain—E. Colburn the father of Zerah, and Connell. Dr Cooke wanted to borrow money of me again— I told him that I wished him to wait until I shall know that his former Bill has been accepted— He will call upon me again— Colburn wanted me to aid him in a plan to get subscriptions for the memoirs of Zerah, to contain the disclosure of his secret, in the United States— He has he says at last found patronage here.
At the recommendation of a gentleman who is himself a mathematician, and to whom Zerah’s secret was disclosed, the Earl of Bristol has subscribed seventy five pounds a year for five years to complete Zerah’s education at Westminster School, where he is now placed, and has promised to double that subscription to carry him through the University of Cambridge— But the father wishing to obtain subscriptions in America for the Book, begged me to recommend persons to him in America who would be willing to promote the subscription, and to whom as well as to myself he would consent to have Zerah’s discovery made known. I declined for my own part the communication of the secret, and advised him to apply to respectable booksellers in the Cities of the United States to promote his subscription and to make it payable at the delivery of the book— He will call upon me again. Connell complained of being quite unwell. He said he saw it stated in a Philadelphia Newspaper, that Stephen Girard, had filled up the subscription to the Bank of the United States, by taking three Millions of the Stock which were wanted to complete it, upon the returns to the first subscription— I requested Mr Smith to ascertain to-morrow whether the order for the exportation of the mint machinery has been dispatched from the Custom House to Liverpool, and to let me know.— There was a small packet containing three numbers of Cobbett’s New-York Register, marked as a ship-Letter from Portsmouth, with a charge upon it of more than thirteen shillings for Postage.— Mr Reeves had been at the Office— It was about seven O’Clock, when I reached home, where I found Dr. Nicholas’s eldest daughter Caroline. She dined and spent the Evening with us. And after dinner, the Ladies played on the Piano and sung till past eleven—

2. VI:45. My Journal engrossed so much of this day that until dinner time I could write nothing else. It was half past five when I walked out; yet I had not completed the Journal of yesterday. The weather was bad almost all the day; which prevented my wife from going to London as she had intended. Nevertheless we had visits from Count and Countess Lieven, who came on horseback from Richmond, where they are passing some days. The Count told me that he expected the Grand Duke Nicholas here at the end of this month or the beginning of the next; and Baron Nicolaï, the late Secretary of his embassy was coming with him— The Count said he was much gratified at this; for Nicolaï having been so long in this Country, would take off from his hands much of the trouble which would otherwise have fallen to his share— He spoke as if had been sufficiently weary of his attendance upon the Emperor when he was here; and much disgusted with that upon the Grand Duchess Catherine; who he said was here so long—who as a lady, required so much more attention, and who from not meeting here that profound respect of etiquette, to which she had always been accustomed on the Continent, and to which she was tenaciously attached was continually imagining she was slighted, and then he was called upon to explain and to remove her dissatisfactions.— The Count also enquired what was the state of our relations and negotiations with Algiers and with Naples.— I received this morning a Letter from Coll. Aspinwall enclosing a memorial from a person named Holland, an American, who solicits relief and assistance to return to America—and sends his Passport from Governor Claiborne. I answered the Letter and returned the memorial and Passport— Wrote also to Messrs. Belles and Harrold, in answer to their Letters of 26 and 28. September. The Ladies played and sung from the Volume of Handel’s Compositions.

3. V:45. My wife went to London, to sit at Leslie’s, accompanied by Ellen Nicholas, Baker, and our Sons John and Charles. I finished a Letter to the President of the United States, and after half an hours walk in the rain, which compelled me to return home, I took up Mr Maury’s account, with the vouchers which occupied me until the Ladies returned. Mr Rotch came out with his Son, whom he introduced to me, and who he said had something to communicate to me of so secret a nature that he himself, could not be present at its disclosure— He therefore went out and walked in the garden while the young man was unfolding to me, his mystery. It was a proposal from a person now an officer in the British Artillery; but not born a British subject; and in principle an ardent republican— He has a great mechanical genius, and has invented an improvement in fire arms which has been approved by the Board of Ordnance, and adopted, but for which, by the report of a Committee of Officers appointed to examine it, but every one of them utterly ignorant of the first principles of mechanics, he had received a compensation, of only five hundred pounds, a sum in his own opinion so inadequate to the merit of the invention that it has given him extreme disgust. But he had another, and a far more important invention in reserve. Its principal use would be in the naval department, but it might also be made useful for war by land. He had written a private Letter to the Duke of York, proposing it in general terms; to which the Duke had answered, by requesting of him a communication in his official capacity— That having been made, the Duke finding that the chief use of the invention was to be for the Navy had referred him to the Lords of the Admiralty, and there, Mr Croker had referred him back to the board of Ordnance, where he would be sure to fall again into the hands of the Committee of ignorant Officers, who had so much undervalued his former invention— He had therefore determined to offer his invention to the Russian Government; but young Rotch having met him, and conversing with him upon the subject had prevailed upon
him to make the proposal to me, of offering it to the Government of the United States. He came therefore to enquire if I, should be willing to transmit the offer to the American Government. The invention, is a projectile, upon a new principle; but of such simplicity that an idea of it could not be given without disclosing the secret; yet of such prodigious effects, impossible to avoid, that with it any sloop of war would be more than a match for any line of battle ship. I told young Rotch that the very magnitude of promise, in such an invention, was a motive for distrusting it. After seeing what had been accomplished by the Steam-engine, it was scarcely possible to say what could not be effected by an application of mechanical powers; but great projects were so common, and great discoveries so rare, that I should not incline to make even a proposal of this kind known to the American Government, without some further knowledge of the person proposing it; and something specific as to the nature and extent of the compensation which he would require or expect— He said that the inventor had been a major in the British service; but having been twice unfortunately involved in duels, and consequently twice compelled to quit his regiment, and rise again from the lowest rank, he was now only a lieutenant. He could not leave the British Service, without having a certainty of employment elsewhere; and he had told him that if his invention should be approved and adopted by the American Government, he thought he might fairly expect for it the rank of a lieutenant Colonel in their army. I said that would be very difficult, as he must be aware, how ungracious it would be to the Officers of our Army to have a foreigner thus promoted over their heads— However, I said if the character of the invention could be specified so that its probable usefulness could be fairly judged of, and the inventor would state specifically what he would demand for his compensation, I would mention it to the Government; particularly with the consideration that the inventor though now an officer in the British service, is not a native British Subject— For had he been such, I should not consider it as a fair procedure, from one Government to another, to hold out any encouragement to him in the design of withdrawing him from one service to enter the other. Rotch is to report to him my answer, and I shall hear from him again— But it is another of the projects from the Limbo of Vanity— J. A. Smith enclosed me a Letter from Grubb to him; mentioning that he had ascertained at the Custom-House, that the order to Liverpool for the exportation of the Mint Machinery was dispatched on the 17th. of August. Spent the Evening at sport with the children.

4. VI:30. The boys were to have returned to school this morning, but soon after I rose, Charles was despatched as their Ambassador to me to say that it was Baker’s Birth-day, and consequently to request for them one day more, which I could not refuse. Received a Letter from George, dated the 2d. at Thetford. He says that they arrived on Monday at Cambridge, and there, Mr Joy invited him to proceed with him to Wretham Park, which he readily accepted— On their way they passed through Newmarket at the time of the races, which they saw. Caroline Nicholas spent the day here; and her brother George dined with us— He had sent a Hare, and a pair of partridges of his own shooting, as a present to Mrs Adams. Mr Gini the singing Master also dined with us; and the Evening was enlivened with music and singing by him and all the Ladies. I wrote a despatch to the Secretary of State, and a short Letter to my Mother. George Nicholas, is an undergraduate at King’s College, Cambridge; and though an undergraduate, is a fellow of the College— I made some enquiries of him respecting the course of the Studies there, which are different in every college. They are required to attend four terms every year, for three years and a half. But the terms are so short that they have more than half the year in vacation, and the only exercise that they have to attend, is to a tutor once a day to whom they construe Euripides’s Tragedies— There are however Lectures which it is optional with them to attend or not. The Students of King’s College, are all sent from Eton School, and undergo their examinations there— They enjoy many privileges, and after keeping the regular number of terms, demand their degree, (posco gradum) as of right.

5. VI:30. The weather has been for several days so cold, with almost incessant rains, that I have found it very difficult to write, without having a fire made in my cabinet— Yet I have hitherto avoided it, and this day, it was scarcely wanted— I received a line from Mr J. A. Smith, mentioning that Mr Jonathan Russell had been yesterday at the Office, and would call again this day at three—and a Letter from Mr Grubb to Mrs Adams, respecting the Articles purchased for T. B. Johnson— The vessel
by which they were to have been sent from London to New-Orleans, can obtain no freight and therefore takes no Cargo. Grubb advises that they should be sent by the Canal to Liverpool. I went to London, and called at Brunet’s Hotel, Leicester Square, Mr Russell’s lodgings, but he was gone out— I then called at Craven Street, and after some detention there went to Mr Williams’s in Finsbury Square. He was gone out— I left with his Clerk J. Munro, an order on the Baring’s, in favour of James Maury, the Consul at Liverpool for the sum due on his account of expences for American Seamen, and took Munro’s receipt; and also left word that I wished to send dollars to Boston. Returned to Craven-Street where I found Mr Russell, and young Rotch. He came to inform me that he had been mistaken in supposing that his friend the inventor was not a native British subject— He was—though he had received his education altogether in France— I said then that all idea of his entering the military Service of the United States must be out of the question— But Rotch said he had employed a respectable mechanic in the experiments to try his invention— The mechanic is possessed of his secret— Could it not be offer’d in his name? I said if the Officer would describe the invention and its effects in such a manner as he himself thought proper; in writings, and also the terms on which he would propose to make the communication to the American Government, no use of any name would be necessary—and I would transmit the proposals as anonymous— Immediately after Rotch left the Office, Connell came in— Mr Russell left Stockholm some time since, and after going to Copenhagen to settle an account of Saabye’s came in the Packet from Gothenburg— He goes on Monday for Liverpool, to embark for New-York. C. Hughes goes to Stockholm as Chargé d’Affaires during his absence— I returned home about seven; and after dinner read two Acts of Shakespear’s Henry 4th. part 1.— The polling of the livery of London for the next year’s Lord Mayor closed this day— The present Lord Mayor has 2635 votes— Alderman Combe (though he declined by Advertisement) 2397. and Alderman C. Smith only 1053— This result has very forcibly shewn the temper of the City of London.

6. VII: I attended Church this morning, alone. Prayers for the 17th. Sunday after Trinity were read by Mr Wallington; the Communion service by Mr Carr; and the Sermon was preached by Mr Milman, from Psalm CXLIV:3. “Lord, what is Man.” the drift of the discourse was to urge the peculiar propriety of calling upon the Lord to say what is man, instead of asking the same question of Earth, or of Ocean, and the preacher told his auditory in some detail what Earth and Ocean would answer, if the question should be asked of them— Mr Milman passes for a Genius, because he has written a laughable tragedy, and a lampoon against Buonaparte— He certainly has a fanciful, though it appears to me a fantastic turn of mind. His Sermons are all his own— But there is nothing in them— The prayer against the plague of waters was this day read again, and seems to be more necessary than ever. The rains have scarcely any cessation. The road between this and London was yesterday deeper than I found it any one day, the whole of last Winter— It rained the greatest part of this day. The boys went to the Boston Terrace Chapel, and afterwards walked to Richmond Hill— I walked out before dinner, but was obliged to return from Brentford by the Rain. After dinner we took the boys to school, and spent the Evening at Dr Nicholas’s. Mr Cook the Musician was there, and we had much singing by the Ladies, accompanied by the Piano. Chiefly sacred music. There was thunder and lightening this Night.

7. VII: A Gardener from Brentford, by the name of Styles brought two Letters to kinsmen of his by the same name, living at Kingston, Ulster County, in the State of New-York,—which he requested me to forward. He also shewed me a Letter that he had lately received from one of those kinsmen. I promised to transmit his Letters, and any others that he will bring to me hereafter— George returned home from his tour with Mr Joy to Cambridge and Wretham Park— We had received on Saturday, a hare and a pheasant of their shooting.— The weather was bad and kept us all at home, except an hour’s walk that I took to Brentford before dinner. I wrote to my brother and to Jas Maury. Finished reading Henry 4th. first Part, and read an Act of the second part, after dinner.

8. VI:45. Received this morning a cover of a Letter in Dr. Eustis’s hand writing, and with the Post-mark of the Hague upon it. It contained a slip of paper, apparently cut out from a Letter, but from whom and to-whom is carefully concealed. on the back, of the paper was the superscription of the Letter; but it is scrawled over so that it is impossible to discern what the direction was. The hand-writing looks like a woman’s— I went in the Curricle to London. Stopped at the British Gallery in Pall Mall and enquired for Leslie, but he was not there. At the Office in Craven Street, I found Mr John West— A Letter from John Graham, the first Clerk in the Department of State, enclosing one from C. Hughes, and a Letter from Mr Jefferson to Sir John Sinclair, with a request to have it delivered to him. Hughes’s Letter likewise enclosed one from his father to a relation of his in Ireland, to be forwarded— There was also a pressing Note from Leslie, and three Bills of Charges from the man at the Custom-House,
Hugh Lock—and a file of the National Intelligencer from 27 July to 8. August— I was just leaving the Office, when Mr Davy the Consul appointed for Hull came in, and made enquiries for his exequatur. I desired Mr Smith to call at the foreign Office, and ask for it, and for that of Mr Visger— Mr Lamb came in soon after; an American going immediately to Paris. He says he saw me there last year.— It was thus between three and four O’Clock before I could leave the Office— I called at N. 32 Sackville Street, and left Mr Jefferson’s Letter to Sir John Sinclair— Then went to Leslie’s, and sat until past five—and complying with the request in his note. I was at home about seven. The present Lord Mayor was this day returned by the Court of Aldermen, to serve in the same office, the ensuing year.

9. VI: My wife with Ellen Nicholas went into London and sat to Leslie. My file of Newspapers occupied part of the morning. Made out my Accounts, and wrote Notes to the Prussian Charge d’Affairs Jouffroy, and to John Reeves, in answer to theirs which I have had weeks upon hand. Walk to Ealing and Hanwell. In the Evening I read an Act of the second Part of Shakespear’s Henry the fourth.

10. VI: After the occupation which now daily employs me till Breakfast time, I was engaged all the morning in writing despatch N. 58. to the Secretary of State. Though long, it was completed, and as it should have been written before I am relieved in having it now prepared.— I had only time left for a short walk to Ealing and Brentford. Wrote a few lines. After dinner I read to the Ladies, Beaumont and Fletcher’s Comedy of Rule a Wife and Have a Wife, in Mrs Inchbald’s Collection— This Play, in the Plot, resembles Shakespear’s Taming of the Shrew, and in the Style of Composition Massinger’s New Way to pay Old Debts. It is one tissue of absurdities, and all the incidents and characters are equally out of Nature— The Dialogue is not much better—coarse, indecent and unnatural— The thoughts are strange, but sometimes vigorously expressed. Some of the situations are interesting, and there are occasional flashes of comic humour Moral there is little or none. Received Letters from Saml. Williams, and James Maury.

11. VI:30. A man by the name of Brown, looking like Romeo’s Apothecary came here this morning, and enquired if I had received any letters lately from Mr Crawford, the Secretary of War— I had none— He said that he had been many years employed in the Ordnance Department, and wished to go to America— He had seen Mr Crawford when he was in London; and had explained to him some of the improvements which he proposed to introduce.— Mr Crawford had approved of them, and told him that upon his arrival in America, he would write to him— He next asked if I could furnish him the means of going to America— I could not— I recollected that the same man, had been to me once before. George Nicholas came; and told me that he was going in a Carriage to London, to go thence this Evening to Cambridge— The Carriage, (his father’s) was to return this Evening; and would take me up where I pleased— I accepted his offer of a seat with him; and between one and two he called for me, and I went with him to London— Stopped at the British Gallery, and told Leslie I was going to his Chamber— Alighted at my Office; where G. Nicholas left me— The Coachman was ordered to call for me, at Leslie’s, at five O’Clock.— A young man belonging to New-York came in— Going in two days for Liverpool. After leaving my despatch and Packet, with Smith, I walked to Leslie’s, and sat to him about an hour.— At five the Carriage came, and I came home alone; musing verses all the way; and never found the distance from London so short. On coming home I found a Letter directed to Mr Russell and myself; but upon opening it found it was intended only for him. It was from Mr Billingsly at Harwich; merely offers of Service— After dinner I read to the Ladies two Acts of the Chances, a Comedy by Beaumont and Fletcher, altered by Villiers, Duke of Buckingham.

12. VI:30. Finished my verses— Ellen Nicholas wrote a few days ago some complimentary lines to my wife; and both of them have been urging me for some time to write something for them to set to Music— I pleaded the barrenness of my Imagination as long as I could, but in return for Ellen’s poetry, some thing was become indispensable— In my walk of the day before yesterday, I strained from hard bound brains, two Stanza’s of eight lines, in the amatory style; and as with a serious turn, they would have been ridiculous from me to her, I closed the second Stanza, with a hyperbolical and burlesque idea— Yesterday Morning at breakfast I gave them to her— She was pleased with them; and my wife told me I had never written any, half so
pretty for her— But not being satisfied with them myself, I added several Stanza’s while riding from Town yesterday, and one this morning to conclude, prepared as I was rising from bed— For I can allow to this trifling, only times in which I can do nothing else— But there is an incongruity in the lines, because the additional Stanza’s, instead of the ludicrous character of the second are too serious and even solemn—written, as if from a youthful and ardent lover, and expressing Sentiments which I neither do nor ought to feel, for her. The Love is all merely poetical, but has so much the appearance of reality, that I scruple to shew the lines now they are written— I wrote a short Letter to my father— One to J. Maury, to enclose the Letter for Mr Russell; and a Note to Lady Morgan— Mrs Adams and Ellen Nicholas went to London. John and Charles came home to dinner— Walk to Hanwell with George— Began a Letter to Harris— It was between seven and eight when the Ladies came home— The boys were obliged to leave the dinner table to return to School.— After dinner I read Acts 3 and 4. of the Chances, which is so dull a Play that it was impossible to fix the attention of my Auditory.

13. VII: Received a Letter this morning from Saml. Williams. Attended Church with the Ladies— Mr Milman read Prayers, for the 18th. Sunday after Trinity— Mr Wallington preached the Sermon from Romans V:1. [“]Therefore being justified by faith, we have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ”—it was a sermon of very moderate ability upon the controversial question between Faith and Works. By a moment of inattention when the text was named, I missed hearing it, and could only afterwards collect it by the tenour of the discourse— This and another incident which occurred led me to write some lines, which I prepared in my daily walk, and in the Evening, while the Ladies were playing and singing the Beauties of Handel— There are three Stanza’s which I call a Sunday Hymn. The Ladies after Church paid a visit to Mrs Elmsley— I finished my Letter to Harris— Among the pieces of Handel’s Music performed this Evening were several new ones from Jephtha—Othniel and Acis and Galatea—“Deeper and deeper Still”—and “Waft her Angels to the skies,” we had last week at Dr Nicholas’s. “Cease ye pretty warbling Choir” was sung by Mrs Salmon at one of the Oratorio’s last Spring— The Ladies concluded the Evening with Italian Music.

14. VI:15. My wife went to London, accompanied by Ellen Nicholas— I received Letters—from T. Dickason and Co. upon the case of the William and Mary— From William Church, an American inventing projector, applying for patronage, and recommendations to Russia, and instructions how to obtain Patents— From Thomas Auldjo, Consul at Cowes, in the Isle of Wight, who has just received his new Commission, and has sent it to his brother to apply for the Exequatur—and from Mr Bickham an American Merchant at the Isle of France, complaining that an order from the British Ministry has just been received there, interdicting all commercial intercourse at that Island with foreign Nations— I wrote to my Mother, to W. R. Gray and to S. Williams, and lost a considerable part of the Morning, in searching for a map of Louisiana, to suit Mr Erving— Walk to Gunnersbury and Brentford— [“]I nunc et versus tecum meditare”— Projected an Ode—and brought forth one miserable Stanza. My wife returned home quite unwell; and after dinner had a faint turn, from which however she soon recovered— Ellen Nicholas was vehemently affected by it, until relieved by a shower of tears. Afterwards the Evening being fine and clear (the first for the last three weeks) I surveyed the Stars by Bode’s Uranographia, discovered Fomalhaut a Star of the first magnitude, but which rises little above the horizon in this Latitude, and is never seen at St. Petersburg—and also a number of other Stars in the Monstrum Marinum or Whale.— But it was too Cold for Observation in the open air.

15. VI:15. I went to London in the Curricle; stopped at the British Gallery, and gave notice to Leslie who was there. Then again at Sharpus’s shop, at the Corner of Pall-Mall, and settled the account of the articles purchased by my wife for her brother— Then at the Stationer Williams’s to order a Common Place Book—and at the Boot maker Clarke’s. At the Office in Craven Street, I found Mr S. C. Thacher, Minister of a Church in Boston, who is traveling for the recovery of his health— His complaint is Haemorrhage from the lungs, and I fear is past medecine— He is now by advice of his physicians going immediately to the Cape of Good Hope, and waiting only for a wind. Dr Bollmann had also called at the Office, and promised to come again at three this day; but I could not wait for him— I found at the Office a Letter from the Chevalier de Freire enclosing one from Mrs Bezerra, at Rio de Janeiro to my wife. I went to Leslie’s and sat until five, when it was so dark that he could no longer proceed. While riding in and out of Town, and while sitting at Leslie’s I was employed incessantly upon my Ode; of which I completed the first draft— I prepared this day five Stanza’s— The Ode is therefore in six— To Fortitude.— Written in the manner of Gray— Stanza’s of ten lines—like the Odes to Spring; and on the distant prospect of Eton School— My Ode will pass very well in the Class of Vers de Societé; and I think it no more like Gray, than Allston thinks his Landscape like one of Claude’s— But if ever my Ode should find a Critic, his first reproach will be that it looks like a Parody upon Gray— It might perhaps be taken for a Burlesque upon it— It has a few prosaic lines, and some expressions not lofty enough for Lyric Poetry— I shall leave them for the sake of their energy— After dinner I wrote off the five Stanza’s; and the remainder of the Evening listened to the Music of the Ladies— The Sky became clear, and I had again the opportunity of examining the principal Stars in the head of the Whale— But the trees which surround our house prevent me from seeing more than a small part of the Horizon from any of our windows, and it is so late in the Season that my curiosity is not ardent enough to sally out late in the Evening to Star-gaze— Gini was here to give Ellen a lesson— She answered my Hymn.

16. VI:15. My wife went to London with Ellen Nicholas to look out for a house. I lost some time in making a Copy of my Ode, which no longer pleases me so well as it did yesterday. Could I have chosen my own Genius and Condition I should have made myself a great Poet— As it is, I have wasted much of my life in writing verses; spell-bound in the circle of mediocrity. In my walk this day, I endeavoured to strike out a Subject, upon which to undertake a work of Patience and Perseverance; but in vain— My time was utterly lost— Mr John Reeves called and paid me a visit. I promised to call upon him, and apologized to him for not having done it before.— I explained to him, what I meant, on board the Lord Mayor’s Barge by the different principles on the doctrine of allegiance, which would lead to conclusions different from his. I shewed him the passage in his pamphlet p. 27. of virulent abuse against the United States, and told him I had three objections to it. 1. That it was incorrect in point of fact— It charged the United States with an inconsistency which did not belong to them, and imputed to them upon erroneous premises, bad motives— 2, It was not in good taste— It was incongruous with the rest of the book; which was cool, moderate and argumentative— That passage alone was angry and intemperate. 3. It disqualified us for a cool and friendly discussion of the principle— For it manifested a temper, with which it must be useless, and might be unsafe to reason upon that topic— He certainly did not relish these remarks; and was aukward and ungracious in his attempts to parry them— At first he said Oh! that’s only my mobbing of the pamphleteer. It is not an attack upon the American Government— If you will read the passage attentively you will find it so— I did not allow him the benefit of this subterfuge— I told him I had read that passage, and his whole pamphlet very attentively and could assure him it was a very pointed attack upon the policy of the United States— Mr Hay’s pamphlet with which I was also well acquainted would not bear him out in these charges.—and said I, in the next edition of your work, I expect you will strike out that passage.— But said he, if all the rest is cool and moderate, and logical, with only the exception of that half page, I shall yet come well off. Ay, but said I, that is precisely the point which we should have to discuss; so that the temperance of all the rest is of no avail— But as to your principle itself said I, you acknowledge that you have your authorities against you—Woodeson, and Gwyllim in his Edition of Bacon’s Abridgement—“All Nonsense,[”] said he— The Lawyers all talk nonsense as well as others— But let it come to Westminster Hall—there it would not last five minutes— I doubted whether the Judges in Westminster Hall would be exactly of his opinion, and told him of the case of Crosby of New-York, whose Estate had escheated in the Island of Jamaica, and then granted to distant collaterals— He had no reply ready for this. I asked him where he got his principle. He appeared to me to have drawn it altogether from Lord Coke’s report of Calvin’s case. But what analogy could there be between the consequences of a king of Scotland’s coming to the crown of England, and those of a Revolution by which the People of North America were separated from the British Empire?— He said he did not want Calvin’s case at all. He took his principle from the definition of the term Alien, in all the Books—“a person born out of the King’s allegiance.”— I asked him if he took a Hanoverian to be a British Subject—entitled to the rights and privileges of an Englishman— At first he said that might be a question— But afterwards he said no— Because the King was Sovereign of Hanover by another title, and not as king of England— I told him that the Common Law was made before England had Colonies— There was nothing like Colonies in it— He said there were the Provinces in France— He had Ladies waiting for him at the gate, which shortened our conversation— He asked me to come some day and dine with him— He always dined, not at those newfangled hours; but at four O’clock; he drank tea at half past five; and at six was seated at his books; to put down these pamphleteers— When he had got half way to the gate, he came back to congratulate me, upon the re-election of our friend the Lord Mayor— That’s what I told him said he, when the Ministers did not go to his dinner. The way for you, said I, is to be the best Magistrate that the City ever had— And that is what they have rechosen him for— Politics would not have done it— He had also talked much about the good-fortune of Lord Exmouth— He had finished a War, in a single day— He had been completely successful— The object was the abolition of Christian Slavery in Africa—and now it was finished, every body was of his side— Nothing could be more fortunate— On this article I fully agreed with Mr Reeves, but I expected he was going to take to himself the merit of Lord Exmouth’s success, as he seemed to ascribe to himself, the re-election of the Lord Mayor— I do see the bottom of this Justice Shallow. Mr Reeves is a lawyer, of a contracted
understanding, active industry and stubborn temper; always a useful instrument in the hands of the Government, but sometimes troublesome by his obstinacy, and sense of his own importance— For he imagines himself to be the main Spring of the Universe— This doctrine of his that Americans born before the Revolution, are not Aliens in England is as crafty, as it is absurd— The absurdity is in the pretended common Law principle of unalienable allegiance; but the craft is his own. He knows that by pushing the Tory principle to its consequences, while he flatters the passions, prejudices, and mortified vanity of the Government and People, they will take special care that it shall never practically operate otherwise than as it shall suit themselves; and that they will take all the advantage of his argument when it operates in their favour. This pamphlet indeed displaced him from the alien Office; but the Government have always good hold of him and he of them. I told him that the charge he had brought against us of seducing foreigners from their allegiance, might be retorted much more forcibly upon his own doctrine; but he said he only reasoned from the Law as it is— He advanced no new doctrine— He only adhered to the old established maxims of the Law of England— The Ladies returned from London before six. The Evening was fine— I finished reading the Chances; and began the Road to Ruin.— Received a Letter from J. A. Smith, asking for a paper; and one from W. and J. Brown at Liverpool; complaining of extra Tonnage duties for Light-Money and Pilotage still levied upon American Vessels. Observed the Stars, from my windows, and with Ellen Nicholas in the Garden.

17. VII: I have refrained from having a fire made in my cabinet, this Season as long as I could write without one. But this morning after holding out until Breakfast, I was obliged to give over the struggle, and the fire was made— I wrote by it until past four; the Journal of yesterday— I then walked to Ealing and across the fields to Hanwell— Musing for a subject upon which to write verses— Abandoned that upon which I began yesterday— Attempted a Fable. Arranged two Stanza’s of alternate rhymes— The Ballad Stanza; a measure for which I have a partiality— Eight and Six— But my Stanza’s were very bad, and the plan of my Fable upon reflection disgusted me— I am continually reminded of Cibber in the Dunciad— Round him much embryo, much abortion lay; Much future Ode, and abdicated Play.— The success of my Sunday Hymn, and of my Ode to Fortitude, has put me in the Condition of novice gamblers, whom the sharpers entice to ruin, by allowing them to win a few trifles at first— After dinner I wrote off my two Stanza’s, and then to atone for so much trifling, wrote Letters to H. Visger, Consul at Bristol and T. Auldjo, Consul at Cowes. The Ladies amused the Evening with Music— Gini had been here this Morning and given a lesson. A clear evening. I observed the Stars from my window— Saw Fomalhaut rise; and the Star called Deneb Kaitos in the whale’s tail. Marked particularly the principal Stars in Aquarius, and those in the tail of Capricorn, where Saturn is. But I discovered no new Stars.

18. VI:45. Awaked before day light this Morning, and lay an hour, arranging a new set of Verses— Penned two Stanza’s immediately after I arose— The Ladies went to London. I received a Letter from W. A. Barron, an old College Classmate of mine, requesting me to ascertain and give him information, whether there was money onboard of a British Sloop of War, called the Hussar, which was sunk at Hellgate, near New-York, during the War of the American Revolution. Barron is one of a Company, who by diving-Bells have undertaken to raise this Ship— They have brought up her guns, and some other Articles; but have not found the money. So as their operations are expensive, Barron writes to me to enquire of the Admiralty here, whether there was any onboard the ship when she sunk— I walked by the Grand Junction Canal to the Osterley Park road and back by Hanwell.— Finished my verses by two Stanza’s added to those of the Morning.— An abortion— Je pourvois par malheur en faire d’aussi Méchans; Mais je me garderois de les montrer aux gens— I began a Letter to my father, and wrote till the Ladies came home, at seven— After dinner we had star-gazing and music. Letter from T. Bigland. Mr Maury’s Clerk— He announces a despatch by the Mail.

19. V:45. Rose with the dawn. The sky was clear, but there was already too much day light for any of the Stars to be visible. I walked from home, leaving orders for the Coachman to overtake me in the Curricle. He overtook me about the fourth Mile-Stone. I went to the Office in Craven-Street, where I found Mr Davy, the Consul appointed for Hull, and Mr Connell, who is going next week to Antwerp. He intends to pass through Ghent, and has promised to bring my picture painted by Van Hüffel with him. Mr Davy goes to Hull but has not settled whether he will stay there— At the Office were also Cards from Mr W. B. Buchanan, at Brunet’s Hotel, and of G. Clymer, who is going early next week to France— The Packet of Despatches from the Department of State, forwarded by Maury’s Clerk was likewise there— It contained a Copy of the Letter of 13. August last from the Secretary of State— A Letter from John Graham, the Chief Clerk in the Department, of 30. August, enclosing Copies—of a Correspondence between Mr Monroe, and the British Minister Mr Bagot, 1. upon the limitation of Armaments upon the Lakes. 2. Upon certain extra duties levied upon British Subjects in the United States 3. Upon complaints of naval outrages on the Lakes— And also further copies of papers relating to our Affairs with Algiers— Besides this there was a smaller packet forwarded by David Gelston, Collector of the Port of New-York, but which with a small packet of Newspapers, merely four or five National Intelligencers, had some how got into the Post-Office, and came from Liverpool, charged as Ship Letters, the despatch with twelve shillings
and eight pence Postage, and the Newspapers with one pound eighteen shillings. I desired Mr Smith to send the Newspapers unopened back to the Post-Office; the despatch I took. It contained a Letter from J. Graham; of 4. September, with two more papers relative to the naval outrage on Lake Erie. There was also a packet containing two of Cobbett’s New-York Register’s— I went up to Leslie’s, and sat to him until five; when I returned home. The latter part of the ride was excessively dark. I found John and Charles at home, from School— I spent the Evening in reading my despatches, which were voluminous; and in writing twenty lines of a new subject that I have started— An Epistle. It occupied my walk, and both my rides, to and from London— The poetic fountain spouts through all its pipes— Ellen often writes; and my wife this day produced several Stanza’s addressed to Ellen; and others to the Painter about my Portrait, which prove that with a little practice she would write very beautiful verses.

20. VII: While rising this morning, and while walking to Church I arranged eighteen lines upon the internal political situation of England, to be introduced into my projected Epistle. George was unwell, and did not attend Church. Nor the Ladies. John & Charles went with me. Mr Milman read Prayers, for the 19th. Sunday after Trinity, and Mr Carr, preached from Ephesians IV:30. “And grieve not the holy Spirit of God, whereby ye are sealed unto the day of redemption.” An indifferent Sermon, but I think the best I have heard from the worthy Vicar.— I walked before dinner to the Windsor road Turnpike, preparing Stanza’s to my wife, in answer to the lines she gave me yesterday— John and Charles returned to School. Part of the Evening I was employed, writing Letters to La Fayette, and to Van Huffel at Ghent. The remainder in listening to the Music of the Ladies.

21. V:30. Wrote to Mr Gallatin, and enclosed to him the Letter for La Fayette. I had risen while it was yet so dark that many of the Stars were visible.— I saw Orion, from our Drawing Room windows.— Yet I barely got through my daily portion of the Index Journal; and a Copy of the Stanza’s to my wife, which I gave her at Breakfast— It was two O’Clock, when I left home, to go into London— Walked to the fifth milestone, a little beyond which I was overtaken by the Coachman with the Curricle. At the Office in Craven-Street, I found a Packet, with the ship-Letter Post-Mark upon it; forwarded by Mr Dearborn the Collector, at Boston; enclosing a despatch from the Department of State for L. Harris, Chargé d’Affaires at St. Petersburg— Two Letters from my father to me; and one from my Mother—with several others for George, and one for Charles— A Letter from P. Coombs, at Bangor, about some Estate of his upon Moose Island— A Note from Earl Bathurst, answering my Note of 25. September, relative to the American Consul’s shipping American destitute Seamen, in American Vessels— A refusal of my request. a Letter from J. Reeves, about his pamphlet and the Ante-nati Americans. And a Letter from James Mack, an Inventor, ruined by persons having votes for Members of Parliament; and wishing to have his expences defrayed in going to America, to produce his invention there. A Land Carriage to travel without horses or Steam.— I left the Letter for Mr Gallatin and the packet of Books for Genl La Fayette, from Lady Morgan, to be sent by Mr Clymer; that for Van Hüffel to be given to Mr Connell; and desired Mr Smith to forward by the Post to-morrow, the Packet for Harris; under cover to Meyer and Brüxner. Mr G. Joy came in, and sat half an hour— I walked from the Office, and was overtaken by the Coachman in Hyde Park— Home before seven. The inventor Mack; had been here for an Answer to his Letter; and left a Note. He writes like an insane man— I wrote this day fifty-two lines, for the Epistle upon which I am occupied. Six, immediately after rising this Morning; and forty six, prepared while I was going into town and returning home. I find not much difficulty in versification, and am at no loss for thoughts— But they come crude and undigested from the mind— It produces as yet only husk without kernel. The rapidity with which I find myself able to proceed proves however what I might have done, had I steadily followed the practice of thus employing my hours of exercise— I have been sluggish in the application of my own powers. But the vivida vis animi is yet wanting; may it be yet supplied! This Evening was occupied in writing down the lines I had meditated, and it being too cold to sit in my Cabinet, I wrote in the Drawing-Room— The Ladies played on the Piano and Sung, till past Midnight.

22. VII: I received this Morning, under Cover from J. A. Smith. My brother’s first of Exchange, for £340 Sterling in favour of John Parker, dated 23. July. endorsed J. Parker— Jno. W. Langdon, and Joh: Joach: Ambrosius, in German, payable to Geo. Cowie and Co— I accepted it payable by Saml. Williams— Recd. also a Letter from W and J. Brown at Liverpool; and one from
N. Ingraham junr. enclosing copies of a Letter from Lord Exmouth to Mr Shaler; dated Bay of Algiers, the second of September last, returning thanks to Shaler for his kindness and good-Offices to the British Consul, and to the Officers and Boat’s Crew of a British ship, who had been confined in a dungeon by the Dey, and nearly starved—and of Shaler’s answer. The papers are very much to Shaler’s honour.— After my journalizing task, I began the Draft of a Note to Earl Bathurst, in reply to that yesterday received from him but did not finish it— Gini was here to give his lesson— And dined with us. He was obliged to go at seven, and to accommodate him we dined at half past five— My walk was thereby abridged to less than an hour. In the Evening, with Music by the Ladies I had some Stargazing, but saw nothing new. I wrote forty-six lines for my Epistle, which is now a mere Chaos. I begin however to perceive inconvenience, from my application to it. For this Evening after retiring to bed nearly at midnight, my thoughts were involuntarily worrying for a rhyme, till Sleep threatened to jilt me for the Night. It was late before I found repose.

23. VI:30. Received a Letter from Coll. Aspinwall, asking an order for £500 on the Brothers Baring and Co. on the Seamen’s fund. Answered the Letter and enclosed the Order— Answer also James Mack’s Letter, and that from W. & James Brown, Liverpool. By the second Post received a Letter from T. Auldjo, Consul at Cowes. My wife went into London, and sat to Leslie; taking Ellen with her. I finished the draft of a Note to Earl Bathurst— Walked along the Canal to the Osterly Park road Bridge and back by Hanwell— Continued, without finishing the Letter to my father— The Ladies came home just before Seven— After dinner, I wrote the lines I had prepared for my epistle, during my walk—32. with 8 written immediately after rising this Morning and then read to the Ladies two Acts of the Country Girl.

24. VI:15. Wrote twelve lines for my Epistle this Morning immediately after I rose. Laura and Charlotte Nicholas were here while we were at breakfast. The Doctor sent me a subscription paper for a dinner at the new Inn, on Saturday next week—2. November, in honour of the Duke of Kent’s Birth-day, which I signed— Went to London with the Ladies. They left me at Craven Street, and Mrs Adams went for her final sitting to Leslie. I walked down to the City, and at the Bankers Robarts, Curtis, Robarts Curtis and Co. received payment of T. B. Johnson’s Bill, for £ Sterling— I had read in the Courier that came yesterday Morning, an Advertisement of a Patent instrument called a writing Renovator, alledged to assist persons whose hands shake in writing— I called at the shop where it was advertised N. 16. Cornhill, and took one of them— It is a gold ring to be worn on the second joint of the fore-finger with a holder for the pen. The invention is of extreme simplicity, and was advertised with so much quackery of Style, that I much distrust its usefulness. But its professed object is of such extreme importance to me that I determined to try it. I also stopped at Pepys’s and took a penknife for the left hand. On my return, I stopped only a moment at Craven Street, and walked homeward— I had agreed to be at Hyde Park Corner, at half past four O’Clock, and then was to walk on till the Ladies should overtake me in the Carriage. I had passed the fourth milestone and it had begun to rain when they did overtake me. On reaching home we found our Sons John and Charles, who had come from School to dine with us. The rain prevented them from returning this Night— After dinner while they were amused with various sports, I was writing the lines that I had been preparing in the course of the day, in my ride with the Ladies, and my walks in the Streets of London, and from Hyde Park Corner, until they took me up. I wrote 54 lines— But ranging over an extensive subject I had merely struck out the first thoughts, and left imperfect so large a proportion of the rhymes that I had some difficulty to recollect them— I was painfully engaged the whole Evening, in tackling anew the rhymes together, and they are yet fearfully bad.— At the Office in Craven Street, I received a Note from Mr Chester, enclosing a Notification from the Lord Chamberlain’s Office that Her Majesty’s Birth-day, which falls on the 18th. of January will be celebrated by a Drawing Room, at the Queen’s Palace on the 6th. of February: and that the Birth-day of His Royal Highness the Prince Regent will also be celebrated by a Drawing Room at Her Majesty’s Palace on St. George’s day the 23d: of April— It is most earnestly recommended and desired that the Nobility and Gentry, and all persons attending upon these occasions will appear in Dresses entirely of British Manufacture. The same notification has been published in the Gazette, and Newspapers, and I suppose the object of issuing it six Months before hand, is to enjoy the popularity of the recommendation to wear British Manufactures.

25. VII: The boys returned this Morning to School. I wrote ten lines prepared as I was rising, and sixteen which I had meditated yesterday, but which had escaped my recollection last Evening. The day was so cold and stormy that I found time only for a short walk to Brentford before dinner— This of course shortened the contribution to my Epistle, for which I wrote only 20 lines. I made a fair Copy of the Note to Earl Bathurst; used the writing renovator the whole day. It remains doubtful whether I shall derive any essential benefit from this instrument. In some respects I find it an assistance; but while it steadies a little the fingers, and holds the pen, it cramps the motion of the whole hand. I do not find that it enables me
to write quicker, or more than I could without it. I received an invitation from the Stewards for a subscription Ball, at the New-Inn, on Monday 4. November, in honour of the Duke of Kent’s Birth-day— Sent by Dr Nicholas: After dinner I finished reading the Country Girl, a Comedy of Wicherley’s, modernized by Garrick. The Play of Mrs Jordan’s principal triumph.— After which the Ladies played and sung. I had written so little that I went to bed, with verses running in my brain. This is the anniversary of the Marriage of my Parents, who were married in 1764. It is also that of the accession of George 3. to the throne of England in 1760.

26. VI:30. Waking early this Morning, the verses immediately recurred again to my mind; and on rising I wrote thirty lines. After breakfast I went into London, walking from home and overtaken by the Coachman and Curricle, between the fourth and fifth mile-stones. I called at the Office in Craven Street, and left the Copy of the Note to Earl Bathurst, for Mr Smith to make out the Note and send to him.— I found a Letter from Mr Maury. Went immediately to Leslie’s and sat to him about two hours. While I was there, Mr Hinkley of Boston came, and requested a Letter to Mr Pinkney at Naples. He is going there to endeavour to recover some property that he had there in the hands of the house of Gibbs at Palermo, which failed— He is to leave London on Tuesday and I promised to send him the Letter on Monday. I went into Mr Allston’s chambers and saw his Picture of Rebecca, and the Steward of Abraham at the Well, which he has just finished for Mr Van Schaick of New-York, and is about to send to him— The days have shortened so that Leslie was obliged to stop before five, and I was at home by half past six. After dinner I was engaged in writing the lines I had been arranging on the road. 68. but so loosely put together that they must be revised with more rigour than I shall be willing to bestow upon them— This facility is dangerous and treacherous; at the close of the Evening, I read a couple of Pope’s versifications from Dr Donne’s Satires.

27. VI:15. On rising this Morning I wrote eight or ten lines, and in the course of the day about thirty more. We all attended Church. Prayers were read, by Mr Carr, for the twentieth Sunday after Trinity, and the Sermon was by the Revd. Henry Hart Milman, fellow of Brazen-Nose College Oxford. from 2d. Epistle of John v. 4. “I rejoiced greatly that I found of thy children walking in the truth, as we have received a commandment from the Father.” It was a Charity Sermon, followed by a Contribution for the Charity School of Girls. Better than the usual average of Mr Milman’s Discourse’s— His principal fault is a mixture of high flown figurative language, with low and ordinary colloquial expressions. His style is a broken winged bird, fluttering along with continual attempts to fly; and as continually brought down by its gravitation to the Earth. On my return home I found Mr Mack, waiting for the answer to his Letter— I sent it three days ago to Craven-Street, but he had not called there to receive it. I told him I could give him no assistance, either to go to America, or to complete his invention. He is a Scotchman, and speaks with a broad accent. Mr Hamilton, of the Woodlands paid a visit— He now resides at Richmond— Mr J. A. Smith came out from London to spend the day with us. Mrs Adams brought home with her Laura and Charlotte Nicholas, who dined with us. I walked with George along the Canal down to Brentford. The Ladies played and sung after dinner— Frank Nicholas spent the Evening with us. I wrote a Letter of Introduction for Mr Hinkley, to Mr Pinkney at Naples.

28. VI:30. J. A. Smith returned this Morning to London, and sent me out by the three-penny Post a budget of Letters and despatches which I received while at dinner— Letters from John Graham, of the Department of State, with duplicate Copies of the papers relating to our Affairs with Algiers, which I had received on the 19th. instant— Mr Graham requests me to send these, after taking Copies of such as I had not before received, to Mr Harris or Mr Pinkney at St. Petersburg— There is only an extract of a Letter from J. Simpson the Consul at Tangier, and a short Letter from the Chevalier Onis to Mr Monroe, that I had not received. There was also an enclosure of a despatch to Mr Harris at St. Petersburg—a Letter from Dr. W. Thornton enclosing one for Mr del Real—and a duplicate of the Letter received a few days ago from W. A. Barron. One of the Packets from the Department of State was so heavy, weighing more than five ounces, that it had been sent back to Mr Smith from the three-penny Post Office— So he had opened it and sent it to me divided into two Packets. Notwithstanding their formidable appearance these packets employed very little of my Evening— I walked to Hanwell and Ealing. Wrote 24 lines for my Epistle on rising this Morning; and 24 lines composed during my walk, and as I am drawing towards the close of my subjects I began
to make out a connected copy of it. Hitherto I have written at random— Scraps and fragments starting from one topic to another as the humour of the moment prompted; though always with an eye to the unity of the composition. The choice of my subject admits this desultory mode of writing. The Epistle is addressed to my Mother— At the close of this Evening I read Pope’s Epistles to Arbuthnot and to Fortescue— One object of my reading Pope’s Poetry now, is to observe more particularly than I have done the peculiar artifices of his versification— Another is to make myself dissatisfied with my own work; which it every effectually does. It would be perhaps better for myself if the effect were to make me burn my Epistle; but that it will not accomplish— I argue to my own heart that my great purpose is to give pleasure to my Parents; especially to my Mother.

29. VI:15. Received this Morning a Note from J. A. Smith with Letters from my father and mother to me; one from my Mother to my wife, and several to George from his Old Schoolmates. They were old Letters, dated in May and June— They had been brought by Mr Hinkley, who more than three Months ago arrived at Liverpool. He gave them to a Mr De Tacy coming to London; but his Trunk was stolen from him with my Letters in it; and recovered only a few days since, by the Bow Street Officers— I wrote a Letter to my brother, after sending by the Morning Post a packet for my Father to J. A. Smith, to be forwarded this Evening to Liverpool— My walk was short; only to Brentford; and I composed only twelve lines while walking— I had written 24 immediately after rising this Morning. Dr Nicholas’s daughters were here this Morning, and Caroline, the eldest, dined with us. Gini was here and gave them a Lesson. In the Evening we all went to a Lecture upon Galvanism at Laws’s tavern, by Ferguson Hardie, a Scotchman, styling himself Lecturer to the Prince Regent. It was intermingled with recitations, declamations and imitations— The last were by Mrs Sumbel, formerly Mrs Wells, who gave imitations of Mrs Siddons in the fatal marriage— Of Mrs Siddons and Mrs Crawford in Jane Shore, and Alicia— Of Mrs Jordan in Nell, and Rosalind’s Epilogue to As you like it, and of Mrs Wells (herself) in Cowslip and Lingo— I had seen Mrs. Well perform the part of Cowslip, with Edwin in 1783. I saw her for the first time perform the part of Isabella, at the Haymarket Theatre in 1784. and remember that her performance was then noticed as a good imitation of Mrs Siddons— I had seen Mrs Crawford in tragic parts about the same time; and Mrs Jordan in 1796 as Nell. I had therefore a curiosity to see Mrs Sumbel’s imitations. this Evening. She was a delicious and favourite Cowslip in 1783. and a fac-simile of Mrs Siddons’s Isabella in 1784— That is thirty two years passed; in which time her years and weight have more than doubled. She is now near sixty and of unwieldy bulk. She has been unfortunate, and it is said disordered in mind. But her imitations were still amusing; particularly those of Mrs Siddons. Collins’s Passions— Dryden’s Alexander’s Feast and Pope’s Ode to St Cecilia were declaimed well enough though with some rant, by a young Man named Chapman; and a Monody upon Sheridan, written by him was delivered by another young man named Harrington— They also read Scenes from the Honey Moon and the Mayor of Garrett— The Lecture was entertaining; and the experiments with the Battery upon a frog, a rabbit and a Sheep’s head successful— He likewise made some chymical experiments, fir’d some soap bubbles, and exploded others. Turned green waters red and red waters green—mixed together many of the gazes—composed a burning mountain; made spirits of hartshorn, and some other surprizing things— It was over, about ten O’Clock. Dr Nicholas and Mr Carr were there with their families. Many of the Doctor’s pupils, and Mrs Riley’s School of Girls filled Laws’s new Assembly Room— We had called at the Doctors for our Sons John and Charles. As I sat next to the Lecturer’s table, he without knowing me, asked me to assist him in some of his Experiments. Being after wards told who I was, he apologized to me, for which there was no occasion, and gave me for my Son, George a small Zinc pallet and a Silver plate with a connecting hook to make the little experiment with the tongue— This entertainment absorbed the Evening.

30. VI:15. The weather prevented me from going into London— I wrote upon rising this Morning 26 lines; and in my walk to Gunnersbury and Brentford composed 30, which I wrote partly before, and partly immediately after dinner— Wrote also despatch N. 60 to the Secy: of State, and copied about 130 lines of the projected Epistle— Read to the Ladies several of Pope’s imitations of Horace, and among them the Epistle to Augustus— The exquisite harmony of Pope’s versification does not proceed from the accuracy of his rhymes— On the contrary, a great proportion of his rhymes are incorrect. So are Gray’s. Their harmony consists in their numbers.— The Ladies closed the Evening with Music.

31. VII: I went into London in the Curricle, which was left there for some repairs. Stopped at the British Gallery and gave notice to Leslie. I had taken with me the despatch for L. Harris, and the Letter to Mr del Real, which I left with Mr Smith to be forwarded and delivered. I found at the Office the Scotchwoman, who had come to me about her daughter and Grand-children, Relations of Mr Williams, and whom I then advised to apply to him— She came now to thank me for advice, and to tell me that she had
followed it— She had been to Mr Williams who had received her with great kindness. Had provided for the children, and would assist her daughter. He had done for them every thing that she desired or asked, and had promised any other assistance that might be required— There was a Packet of despatches from the Department of State—only a file of the National Intelligencer from 24. August to 14. September— And a Carmarthen Newspaper from W. Couling— I went immediately to Leslie’s, and sat to him for the last time. He has asked our permission to send the Portraits to Philadelphia, to the Public Exhibition there next May, before sending them to Mr Johnson at New-Orleans. From Leslie’s I walk’d to the Oxford-Street gate entrance to Hyde-Park; across the Park to Kensington Gate, and to the third Milestone, where being overtaken by a Stage, I stopped the Coachman, and took an inside seat— I found there four Ladies as travelling Companions— At the corner of Boston Lane I left them, in Brentford, and walked home— It was then just seven— I had been all day meditating verses; while going into town and coming out. After dinner I wrote 54 lines; and had written 8. on rising this Morning— Read Pope’s imitation of Horace Ep: 2. B. 2. And the first Dialogue of the Epilogue to the Satires.

Day. The index to my Journal now occupies every Morning from my rising until Breakfast time; with the exception of the employment occasioned by a rhyming, I wish I could say a poetical paroxysm which seized me about the middle of this Month and which has not yet entirely spent its force. It began by a couple of joking Stanza’s to Ellen Nicholas, and is now drawing to a close in an Epistle of 5 or 600 lines to my Mother— As I usually wake an hour or more before day-light, I lie musing verses until it penetrates through the corners of the window shutters, and while I am then rising and dressing— I write these lines down as soon as I come into my Cabinet—then betake myself to the index, and when the Newspapers come in, look over them. We Breakfast usually between ten and eleven. After Breakfast I write my Journal and Letters until four or five. Then walk an hour— Sometimes an hour and a half during which I muse verses— Write them down upon my return; or immediately after dinner. Our dining hour is six. But when any of us go in to London, we never sit down to table sooner than seven; and sometimes not much before eight— We have had no calls to London this Month to parties of any kind; but each of us about twice a week to sit to Leslie— I have had much relaxation from business, and received and written unusually few Letters; when I go into town, I compose both going and returning, lines which I write down in the Evening at home— Sometimes, as this day amounting to between 50 and 60. Sometimes there are lines that slip from my Memory; and some times they afterwards recur to it— This recurrence principally happens in the Morning. Some lines are more striking to me at the moment of composition than others— These scarcely ever escape from my recollection, and often serve as a sort of pointing-Post to the rest. I think my time was never more completely employed. I commonly close the Evening, by reading a half an hour or an hour to the Ladies; and by listening to their Music— From eleven to twelve is the hour for retirement.
